data.title: The 25+ Best Movies Directed By Ron Howard
data.meta_description: Over 600 filmgoers have voted on the 25+ Best Movies Directed By Ron Howard. Current Top 3: Apollo 13, A Beautiful Mind, Cocoon
data.text:
Ranked By

3.5K votes

669 voters

1 reranks

With more than 650 movie fans casting votes, this list of the best movies directed by Ron Howard is a must-see for fans of his work. Throughout his illustrious career, Ron Howard has helmed some truly memorable films. From the blockbuster fantasy of Willow to the epic drama in A Beautiful Mind, there's something for everyone in his body of work.

What makes these movies so special? It could be their engaging characters and humor—many of Howard’s films feature charismatic actors who bring plenty of wit and charm to their roles which help draw us into the story. Or it could be that he manages to capture every emotion onscreen – from wide-eyed wonderment to deep sorrow – with equal skill and finesse. Whatever it is, these movies show why Ron Howard is one of our greatest living filmmakers today.

So if you're a fan of great storytelling or just want an enjoyable way to spend your evening, take a look at this ranking and vote up your favorite Ron Howard films.

Latest additions: Jim Henson Idea Man

Over 600 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The 25+ Best Movies Directed By Ron Howard

Tom Hanks, Bill Paxton, Kevin Bacon

Released : 1995

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Historical drama, Space Adventure, Survival, Docudrama

Why Should I Watch Apollo 13: Traverse the perils of space in this suspenseful retelling of NASA's ill-fated lunar mission, highlighting Ron Howard's expert direction and a stellar cast led by Tom Hanks. Themes of unity, determination, and optimism prevail as engineers race against time to bring their astronauts home safely. Meticulous historical accuracy and impressive visual effects render Apollo 13 an essential viewing for space aficionados and fans of high-stakes drama.

Apollo 13, a gripping space docudrama, chronicles the real-life, perilous lunar mission of 1970. The film features astronaut Jim Lovell (Tom Hanks), command module pilot Ken Mattingly (Gary Sinise), and flight director Gene Kranz (Ed Harris). When an oxygen tank explodes, the spacecraft's crew must abort their moon landing, transforming their mission into a struggle to return home safely. Directed by Ron Howard, Apollo 13 masterfully blends historical accuracy with cinematic suspense. It was nominated for nine Academy Awards in 1996, underscoring its significant impact on the genre of true-story films.

Russell Crowe, Ed Harris, Jennifer Connelly

Released : 2001

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Psychological drama, Biography, Romance, True Story

Why Should I Watch A Beautiful Mind: Experience the brilliant yet tormented life of mathematician John Nash through Russell Crowe's riveting performance in this biographical drama directed by Ron Howard. The film offers a compelling exploration of intellect and mental illness while showcasing captivating storytelling and award-winning acting from Crowe and Jennifer Connelly. A Beautiful Mind remains a powerful portrayal of schizophrenia's influence on both personal relationships and professional achievements.

A Beautiful Mind is a biographical drama, chronicling the life of John Nash (Russell Crowe), an extraordinary mathematician grappling with schizophrenia. The plot unfolds in the mid-twentieth century, tracing his rise to acclaim and descent into mental chaos. His wife, Alicia (Jennifer Connelly), stands as a pillar of support through his tumultuous journey. Directed by Ron Howard, the film scooped up four Academy Awards, including Best Picture. An engrossing narrative of genius and resilience, it's a profound exploration of human intellect and its frailties.

Don Ameche, Wilford Brimley, Brian Dennehy

Released : 1985

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Science Fiction, Family drama, Adventure, Comedy

Why Should I Watch Cocoon: Rediscover youthfulness with this fantastical sci-fi adventure featuring senior citizens who uncover extraterrestrial rejuvenation secrets. Helmed by Ron Howard, Cocoon interweaves humor, heartfelt emotion, and otherworldly experiences while addressing themes such as aging gracefully and embracing novel opportunities. Memorable performances from veteran actors like Don Ameche, Wilford Brimley, and Hume Cronyn add emotional depth to this timeless tale that transcends generations.

In Cocoon, a group of elderly Floridian friends, including Ben Luckett (Wilford Brimley) and Art Selwyn (Don Ameche), stumble upon an abandoned pool infused with an alien life force. After swimming in the pool, they find themselves rejuvenated, their vitality restored. Meanwhile, the aliens, disguised as humans led by Walter (Brian Dennehy), are on a mission to retrieve their lost comrades cocooned at the bottom of the ocean. The movie's blend of science fiction and drama earned it an Academy Award for Best Visual Effects. Yet, amidst the extra-terrestrial spectacle, it is a tale of aging and the quest for immortality.

Russell Crowe, Renée Zellweger, Paul Giamatti

Released : 2005

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Sports drama, Historical drama, Biography, Romance

Why Should I Watch Cinderella Man: Witness the tenacity of an underdog boxer portrayed by Russell Crowe in this inspiring biographical sports drama chronicling James J. Braddock's journey from destitution to heavyweight champion status. Directed by Ron Howard, Cinderella Man presents a detailed depiction of Depression-era America while emphasizing the power of courage amidst adversity. Evocative cinematography, a moving script, and superb performances from Crowe and Renée Zellweger make this film a must-see.

During the Great Depression, ex-boxer James J. Braddock (Russell Crowe) works as a day laborer until his former manager Joe Gould (Paul Giamatti) offers him a one-time slot against a rising young contender. After he wins a shocking upset, Braddock goes back into the ring full time, against the wishes of his frightened wife, Mae (Renée Zellweger). Dubbed "The Cinderella Man" for his rags-to-riches story, Braddock sets his sights on the defending champion, the fearsome Max Baer (Craig Bierko).

Kurt Russell, William Baldwin, Robert De Niro

Released : 1991

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Action, Adventure, Crime Thriller, Drama

Why Should I Watch Backdraft: Venture into the perilous realm of firefighting and arson investigation in this intense action drama led by an all-star cast including Kurt Russell and William Baldwin as two conflicted firefighter brothers entangled in a lethal conspiracy. Directed by Ron Howard, Backdraft immerses viewers through its high-stakes action scenes, edge-of-your-seat suspense, authentic firefighting sequences, and emotive storytelling. This film ignites a newfound appreciation for firefighters' bravery and dedication to their profession.

Chicago firefighting brothers Stephen (Kurt Russell) and Brian (William Baldwin) have been rivals since childhood. Brian, struggling to prove himself, transfers to the arson unit. There he aids Don (Robert De Niro) in his investigation into a spate of fires involving oxygen-induced infernos called backdrafts. But when a conspiracy implicating a crooked politician and an arsonist leads Brian back to Stephen, he is forced to overcome his brotherly competitiveness in order to crack the case.

Mel Gibson, Rene Russo, Gary Sinise

Released : 1996

Directed by : Ron Howard

For Fans Of: Crime thriller, Drama, Action

Why Should I Watch Ransom: Navigate a world of anxiety, deception, and moral dilemmas alongside Mel Gibson's desperate father character seeking retribution for his kidnapped son in this taut crime thriller directed by Ron Howard. The intricate plot twists keep viewers guessing until the very end as it delves into complex family dynamics and ethical quandaries faced when dealing with criminals. Its superb acting ensemble elevates Ransom from conventional crime drama to an enthralling examination of human emotions under duress.

Through a life of hard work, airline owner Tom Mullen (Mel Gibson) has amassed a great deal of wealth. When a group of criminals want a piece of his cash, they kidnap his son (Brawley Nolte) for a $2 million ransom. Encouraged by his wife (Rene Russo) and an FBI agent (Delroy Lindo), Tom prepares to pay the money, but the ransom drop goes awry. Enraged, Tom decides to turn the tables on the kidnappers by making the ransom a bounty on their heads -- which he announces on national television.
